item.title: Very simple Git workflow
item.description: Simple git workflow Open command prompt and go to your local copy of your repository. cd C:\Workplace\DevOps\reponame\ Create new branch. git checkout -b user/avinash-addNewPackage Make your changes to the local copy of repository. Stage your changes git add * Commit your changes. git commit -m "Adding new package" Push your changes to remote branch. git push origin user/avinash-addNewPackage Go to Azure DevOps and create a pull request to merge your work with master branch.

item.title: Running MS SQL on Linux in AKS
item.description: Creating a kubernetes cluster Login to you azure account az login Create resources #Create a resource group az group create --name rgACR --location eastus #Create an Azure container registry instance az acr create --resource-group rgACR --name dockerSQL2019 --sku Basic #Log in to the container registry az acr login --name dockerSQL2019 #Create an AKS cluster az aks create --resource-group rgACR --name sqlAKSCluster --node-count 2 --generate-ssh-keys --attach-acr dockersql2019 #To configure kubectl to connect to your Kubernetes cluster az aks get-credentials --resource-group rgACR --name sqlAKSCluster #To verify the connection to your cluster kubectl get nodes #Create an SA password in the Kubernetes cluster kubectl create secret generic mssql --from-literal=SA_PASSWORD="ComplexPassword"

item.title: Overview of Back Up & Restore of MS Sql Server Databases
item.description: Managed services on Azure like Azure SQL Database, Azure Synapse (Azure SQL Datawarehouse) & SQL Managed Instances makes it very easy to create a backup & restore strategies. item.title: Mssql Counting Rows
item.description: One can count number of rows in a table in many ways and depending upon the chosen option results may or may not be same. Reason being the way SQL handles NULL while counting. Following are three different ways to COUNT number of rows in a table: Query Results SELECT COUNT(*) returns total row count SELECT COUNT(1) returns total row count SELECT COUNT([Col Name]) returns row count where [Col Name] IS NOT NULL

item.title: Setup Sqlserver Rservices
item.description: MSDN Article here explains in detail the steps required to set up SQL Server R Services (In-Database). For those who have already installed R Services as part of their SQL Server 2016 installation (like me) and looking for enabling the R services, you can open SQL Server management studio and run following command: 1 2 3 Exec sp_configure 'external scripts enabled', 1 Reconfigure with override Open services.msc and restart SQL Server services.
